Status codes:
config.content:
• 0: Success,
  • 10: Test Skipped,
  • 11: Suite Skipped,
  • 21: Failed Assertion Command,
  • 22: WebElement not found,
  • 23: Command timeout,
  • 24: Dialog missing,
  • 25: Wrong WebElement Attribute,
  • 26: Wrong WebElement Tag,
  • 27: WebElement Exception,
  • 28: Javascript Exception,
  • 29: Javascript Timeout,
  • 30: Browser Window Error,
  • 31: Invalid Target,
  • 32: Invalid Value,
  • 33: Preprocessing Failed,
  • 34: Failed Command,
  • 100: Test Timed Out,
  • 200: Failed Test,
  • 300: Invalid Config,
  • 310: Credential Lock Not Available,
  • 320: Invalid Credential Lock Handle,
  • 390: Credential Provider Failure,
  • 400: Session Request Timeout,
  • 410: No Capabilities,
  • 420: Hub Connection Error,
  • 430: Session Not Created,
  • 440: Invalid Hub Address,
  • 450: WebDriver Failure,
  • 460: Viewport Out of Bounds,
  • 500: Test Parsing Error,
  • 510: Duplicate ID,
  • 520: Invalid Test Reference ID,
  • 530: Duplicate Name,
  • 600: System Failure,
  • 1000: Command Parsing Error,
  • 1010: Result Conversion Failure

config.name: Top Selenium Grid Nodes by Session Count (Trend)
What's "Minimal Monitoring"
config.content: "Minimal Monitoring" is a Dynamic Group (provisioned in new LogicMonitor accounts) that automatically populates with devices that LogicMonitor can't communicate with - we're missing credentials, a firewall is blocking something, etc. Think of it as the "homework" folder to get all of your resources properly monitored.

config.name: Linux Servers: Host Availability
Add a "Location" property to a group or resource to see it on the map!
Weather Enabler
config.content:
Dynamic Weather Map Overlay

This text box contains an embedded script that adds a weather layer to the Map widget.

The script looks for the following text (regardless of case) in the Map widget's title and adds the appropriate layer:

  • "Precip" or "Radar"
  • "NEXRAD Base"
  • "NEXRAD Echo Tops"
  • "MRMS" (info)
  • "Temperature" (API key required)
  • "Wind Speed" (API key required)
  • "Satellite" or "Cloud Cover" (API key required)
  • "Fire" (for active wildfire information)

Depending on the map type, weather data comes from RainViewer.com, OpenWeatherMap.org, or the Open Geospatial Consortium (OGC).

If you want to use one of the map types listed above noted as needing an API key (other map types use free, open APIs that don't require a key), you'll need to register for a free account on OpenWeatherMap.org. Once you've obtained an API key, add a new dashboard token named 'OpenWeatherAPIKey' and paste your key into its value field.

Timestamp of radar image:  

You can use the button below if you don't see weather on appropriate map(s) or want to force a refresh.
